Predicting what may befall this climate of England and other kingdoms, for this year 1689 with the account of the memorable eclipses, and their signification, with other remarkable matters worthy of note.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p:
The Great and Wonderful PROPHECIES, OF
Mr. Patridge,
Mr. Coly,
Mr. Tanner, and
Mr. Andrews.
Predicting what may befall this CLIMATE of ENGLAND And other Kingdoms, for this year 1689. With the Account of the memorable Eclip≈øes, and their Signification, with other remarkable matters worthy of Note.

figure.p: Pray: That hee May Turne his Wrath Away ‚òû greate Wonders and Strange „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ

div.p:
Printed for I. C. in Holbourn
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ

div.head: The Great and Wonderful PROPHECIES, OF Mr. Patridge, Mr. Coly, Mr. Tanner, &c.
div.p: TIs no wonder, if ≈øo many ≈øtrange Events and Accidents are hidden from the fore-≈øight of Man-kind, ≈øince ≈øo few addict them≈øelves to the under≈øtanding the Caele≈øtial Intelligences, in their ≈øundry A≈øpects, Motions, Conjunctions and Configurations, ≈øeeing by them as by the Monitors of Heaven, are pointed out the Ri≈øe and Decay of Empires, Kingdoms, and States, Wars, Plague, Famine, Fire, Lo≈ø≈øes, and the like, which the more judicious frequently fore-≈øee; and which, by a true and timely Repentance may be averted, and the Almighty Hand ≈øtay'd, ever then when it is lifted up to give the Fatal Stroke, as appears by the Ninevites Humiliation, David's oppo≈øing him≈øelf to the de≈øtroying Angel, Hezekia's Prayer, that delivered him from appointed Death, and many other Examples found in Holy Writ, and other Warrantable Records, &c. But not to be tedious in the Beginning, I now Proceed to give the Reader the Sum of the Predictions, Prophecies, or Progno≈øtications, for the Year, 1689 As I find them ≈øet down by the≈øe Four mo≈øt Learned and Judicious A≈øtrologers; who≈øe heitherto approved Truths fore-told, have ≈øtruck the World with no ≈ømall Wonder and Amazement.

div.head: This Year, ≈øays Mr. Patridge,
div.p: BEgins with no Extraordinary Action, but Great Councils and Con≈øultations, which may be hoped to very ‚Ä¢ ood Purpo≈øe for at the Po≈øt-ventional New Moon; Two days after its Ingre≈øs the Moon applyes to the Sextile of Saturn, to which may be adde ‚Ä¢ the Conjunction of the Fortunes & the Sextile of the Sun & Saturn which in the St ‚Ä¢ rry, Di ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ects, are Arguments of a Quiet and Peace able Time; and much better (perhaps) than expected, for there are very Emergencies, Good or Bad, that happen in the World, but have ≈øome Manife≈øtation from the Configuration of the Heavens; and they from the Beginning of the Year, till towards the Spring, ≈øeem to Denote nothing le≈øs than a Stabilitie of Worldly Affairs, were not the two Infortanes Stars, ≈øo called, po≈ø≈øited in a Head-≈øtrong, Malicious, and Treacherous Sign; however the Benevolent Po≈øitions of the Favourable, Planets, Mittigate the Evil pretended, from whence we may clouclude, and hope for better Things than many ill Spirited Per≈øons de≈øire; Though to other Countrys, under their Influence to Mars and Saturn in Scorpio, threatned Rebellious Mutinies, War, F ‚Ä¢ l≈øhood, Perjury, ∆≤iolation, or Breach of Leagues, between Neighbouring Princes, Di≈ø≈øen≈øions, Controver≈øies, Murthers, with Ba ‚Ä¢ kbitings among≈øt Relations; ≈øome ≈øiding with one Party or Country, and ≈øome with another; having thus di≈øcour≈øed of the fir≈øt part of the Year; he proceeds to the ≈øecond.

div.head: Saturn, ≈øays Mr. Coly.
div.p:
BEing in Scorpio, and Jupiter in Aquarius; it is an ill Wind that blows no body profit: Things ≈øeem to be in a moderate good Po≈øture; many cry out for Ju≈øtice and plead much Loyalty, ≈øome ≈øticking of an Old Nature, falls in the Quadrate of Saturn, & Mars threatens a Foot of ≈øubtile aged per≈øons, and u≈øually produces many
≈øtrange Effects; and this following the Suns Ingre≈øs, ≈øome Melevolent Malady is to be feared, and the A≈øpects being for the mo≈øt part Partamicable, ≈øeem thereby to promi≈øe ∆≤nity, Concord, Good Agreement, &c. And the Po≈øition of Jove in Aquarius, Denotes Advancement of Worthy Men of the Long Robe, ≈øo that we have cau≈øe to hope well, notwith≈øtanding the Endeavours of ≈øome Wicked Per≈øons to hinder our Tranquilitie; and towards the Clo≈øe of the Spring, hope to hear Good News, even ≈øuch as will prove grateful to all hone≈øt Minds. From the Spring, proceeding to Summer, he ≈øays various Actions and Effects will be produced throughout Europe, and we may wait to ≈øee the Operation of Great Things, which are promi≈øed in Forreign Parts, and ≈øuch, perhaps, that many years before have not produced; for Jove falling Retrogade into Pi≈øces, in Trine, and great Reception with ∆≤enus; with many other favourable or friendly Configurations, from whence we may Naturally expect as propitious Influences; for in any ingre≈øs of the Sun, if the Fortunes are found in their own Dignities or Reception, then do they influence Vertue and ≈øuch Actions as they Naturally ≈øignifie, ≈øhall be exceedingly Augmented: And altho' Eminent Changes happen yet to the Benefit of Mankind, &c. and Ju≈øtice Impartially Executed upon the Great and Powerful, as well as upon the Meaner ≈øort, all Things inclining to peace and Tranquilitie; and ≈øo going on to Antum ‚Ä¢ , or the la≈øt Divi≈øion of the Year,

This Month ≈øays he, meaning September, we have a mo≈øt hateful Oppo≈øition of Saturn & Mars; attended al≈øo with the Oppo≈øition of the Fortunes, Jupiter & ∆≤enus the Square of Saturn and ∆≤enus, the Square of Mars and ∆≤enus from fir'd ≈øigns, which are notable Configurations, & u≈øually produce wonderful Effects; for Mankind is threatned with ≈øtrange Di≈øtempers. of Body, as Fevours, occa≈øioning Megrim, Madne≈øs, Phranzies, Appoplexies, Lethargies; with many other Anonimous Di≈øea≈øes and ∆≤nnatural, hard to be cured, and often terminate in ≈øudden Death, and now expect to hear of many Roberies, and inhumane Actions among≈øt Mankind; as al≈øo Treacherous Enterpri≈øes, & very ≈øudden and amazing Accidents in many parts of Europe, for
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
Nature ≈øtill Acts to bring her Works about:
Mar≈øs gives the Pox, but Saturn gives the Gout;
Seas plagu'd with Pirates, Thieves infe≈øt the Land,
Ea≈øe proves di≈øea≈øes to each unruly Hand.
And thus much for the predictions of this learned Man, from whence we proceed to give you an account of the Predictions and A≈øtrological Judgments of others in General, for the year 1689. as taken from their own hands, &c.

div.head: In the Beginning of the Year, ≈øays Mr. Tanner,
div.p: SAturn being in the A≈øcending part of Heaven, and Jupiter in the Angle of the Earth, ≈øignifie In≈øurrections, oppo≈øing Princes, undermining Government, as al≈øo Mutations and Changes in the Affairs of Princes and States Alterations in Laws, &c. Threatning e≈øpecially the Ottoman Empire, and not looking very favourably upon Italy, and ≈øome of the German Princes, who will be detrimented in their Affairs, and others find ≈øome difficulty and heavine≈øs in the management of their E≈øtates and Government, and the quartile A≈øpect of Saturn and Mars, Denote many bold, daring and unu≈øual Roberies; and if Saturn ≈øhall be in Scorpio, having North Latitude, it threatens abundance of Rain, over-flowing of Rivers, and Sea-banks, corruption of Waters; and if Oriential, it Denotes Wars and Contentions, between Noble men and their Kings and Governours, &c. E≈øpecially tho≈øe Countrys under Aquarius, Scorpio and Leo: Yet as to us, we find that Saturn and Jupiter, are aptly towards their Trine A≈øpects, which carry a ≈øignification of Love and Friend≈øhip along with them, and in May they are partially ≈øo figurated, and ≈øo continue in the following July, intimating En ‚Ä¢ ca≈ø≈øies, Treaties for peace, & hopeful propo≈øals, which will be promoted by ≈øundry well-de≈øigning people, if not hindered by ≈øome Malevolent A≈øpect, ≈øtirring up ≈øuch as may give it a di≈øturbance; however, in the following Quarter, the A≈øpects are more favourable, and give hopes of a great ≈øettlemen of Affairs, which God of his Mercy Giant, e≈øpecially to the≈øe Kingdoms.

div.head: To the≈øe we may add what He ≈øays in his prediction for the Year, 1689.
div.p: THe Configuration of Heaven, (≈øays he) attending the Solar Ingre≈øs, are of a pretty mild and calm Nature, and the heavenly Bodies are moderately di≈øpo≈øed, as to their Mutual A≈øpects, yet to Forreign Countrys they prove not ≈øo favourable, but threatens them with mortal Action, e≈øpecially the Turks, Tartars, Polonians, &c. yet ≈øoon after, Calmne≈øs may probably in≈øue, and we may rea≈øonably expect to hear of a greater Calm, tho' ≈øome other A≈øpect threaten to keep the World in Action; nor are the Eclip≈øe of this to be held of little account in their Effects and Significations, according to the Rules of A≈øtrology, and ≈øince we have ≈øpoke ≈øufficiently of other progno≈øtical Effects, produced by the Plannets and Heavenly Bodys; what is mo≈øt Noted of them, is material to be laid down.

div.head: Of the Eclip≈øes, and what is ob≈øervable from them this year, 1689. according to Mr. Andrews.
div.p:
THe Fr≈øt Eclip≈øe will be upon the 25th. of March, being of the Moon, between the hours of 6 & 7 at Night, being a total & centerial Eclip≈øe, and is to be ≈øeen in England, if the Clouds or Mi≈øts intercept it not. Its beginning will be at 39 Minutes pa≈øt 4 a Clock, the beginning of total Darkne≈øs will be at 45 Minutes pa≈øt Five, the the middle or greate≈øt Ob≈øervation about 44 Minutes pa≈øt Six. The beginning of the Moons Recovering Light; about 43 Minutes pa≈øt 7; & the end about 49 Minutes towards 8, and at the time of the≈øe E ‚Ä¢ lip≈øes, Saturn is in the Fourth Degree of Scorpio, Retrogade in the a≈øcendant: Jupiter and Mars are in the Fourth hou≈øe, Jupiter being in the 23d Degree of Aquarius, and Mars in the 6th. Degree, thereof the Sun and Caput Draconis, are in the 7th. hou≈øe in the 15th. Degree of Aries, and Mercury is in the 6th. hou≈øe, and in the 10th. Degree of the ≈øame ≈øign, Retrograde; but to come near in this matter, it is the Opinion of the Learned, that an Eclip≈øe ≈øo po≈øited, is of no Benevolent Nature, but Denotes, Sorrow, Labour; Impri≈øonment; ≈øecret Contrivences, clande≈øtive Actions, and Negotiations, &c. Wherefore it may may be rea≈øonably conjectured, that tho≈øe Countrys ≈øubject to its
Effects, may happen to fall under ≈øome unexpected Di≈øorder; however, we are of Opinion, that tho≈øe being only ≈øecondary Cau≈øes, prompting and not compelling, may by the over-ruling power of God, be prevented, for in his hands are the Breath of Life and Actions of Mankind, on whom we ought to Rely for our ≈øafety & pre≈øervation.

The ≈øecond con≈øiderable Eclip≈øe is of the Moon, on the 19th. day of September, about half an hour after 2 of the Clock in the Morning, which will be a total and centural Eclip≈øe, vi≈øible with us, if the Air be ≈øerene and not over-ca≈øt with Clouds: The beginning will be about 15 Minutes pa≈øt Midnight; the beginning of total Darkne≈øs, about 56 Minutes pa≈øt one of the Clock; the middle or greate≈øt ob≈øervation, about 48 Minutes pa≈øt two of the Clock; the beginning, or recovering Light, about 44 Minutes pa≈øt three of the Clock, and the end about 46 Minutes pa≈øt four of the Clock, the total Duration about 3 hours and 54 Minutes, and the Digits Eclip≈øed, will be 20 & 39 Minutes, and the mo≈øt material Configurations attending this Eclip≈øe, are the oppo≈øition of Jupiter and ∆≤enus, and of Saturn and Mars, it happening in the Eighth Hou≈øe, called by A≈øtrologers Domus, morts and ends in the ≈øeventh, which they call the Angles of War, Quarrels, Strife, and contentious Mars is Lord of Aries, where the Eclip≈øe falls out, is Retrograde and in his Detriment, ≈øo that the Effects may ≈øeem to be of no plea≈øant Importance, as furthermore happening in the Fiery Triplicity, and fir≈øt Decant of Aries. and in this Ca≈øe, according to the Learned, it Denotes the motion of Armys, Death, and De≈øtruction of ≈ømall Cattle, Enmity between the ∆≤ulgar and Noble ≈øort of people, Murthers, Thefts, Di≈øcords, Wars, ≈øharp Fevours, Apparitions in the Air, and Mutations in tho≈øe parts ≈øubject to the ≈øign, wherein it happens, which we earne≈øtly wi≈øh may be Averted from us and that we may enjoy our Religion, Liberty and Property in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ac ‚Ä¢ and plenty. Amen, Amen.
